Some of the metaphors I often raise are around activities developers no longer do. We no longer write machine code. There came a time when the compiler could better prepare for the nuances of the silicon's optimizations for performance. When hand-written machine code had as much a chance to run slower than it did to run faster.

Sure, you've got a chance to write well tuned hand-written machine code. And you should, at least once, to learn. But we choose into our programming languages seeking a better pace of solving the challenges around us.

I think this is the same, and the abstractions I wrangle directing agentic work are the broader coding abstractions that are taught (or, sadly, mostly not taught) in modern software engineering. I've been seeking new levels of performance in releasing the syntax and focusing on higher order design principles, and it is paying off.

Those of us that know and think in these principles, it's well past time to write that down and teach it. Or pay attention to the people writing it down, and learn and teach that.

For example, we don't want to pre-ordain how instructions fall into the execution pipelines on modern CPUs, that could happen all kinds of ways. Both communities are thriving, but they are both very different, and people will naturally take to one or the other depending on their needs. And in my mind, waste is in predicting and building for a future that can never arrive. A test-driven, reality-driven, emergent approach to code seems most efficient and pragmatic. You could argue that it is both Agile and Lean, though if you win the lottery with your prediction of the future you could save bumping around while a design emerges. In my experience though, it's too high a risk.

Introducing tests to a larger system is difficult, because what influenced its shape is unknown. You look for patterns, try and find boundaries, intrinsic dependencies in the code. Even in this case, though, you can use tests to begin to define boundaries in a messy code-base. If all the code is imperative, it helps you tease out functional or at least testable pieces as you go. This is usually the approach I bring to folks, start with a characterization test and tease out some details as you come to an understanding of the system. Over time, you can end up in the same place at least with portions of the system that you foster forward instead of rewrite. BDUF implies you can predict the future, and I have little faith in that. I have faith in a steady stream of small victories, sometimes very very small, but victories nonetheless. Your team must own the code, not the other way around.

You have a foundational assumption here that the tests and the code are independent of each other. It is easy to see, and obvious to most that the tests depend on the code. Without the code, the tests can't run. However, what ends up being intrinsic in the code is how the tests have influenced its shape, the approach the developer took to writing it because they liked the aesthetic of the test they wrote. When you grok TDD, you realize that the code could never have existed without the tests that helped shape it. So to say that there is lesser meaning in the tests I believe is backwards. There is more meaning in the tests. They are as important as the requirements, without which the code would have no purpose.

I agree, RVM is excellent at setting up specific Ruby interpreters, and even better at keeping clean and non-conflicting gem environments through its gemsets feature, but it's not the only path. I find bundler does a great job keeping your production gemset clean.

However, all gems that compile native library bindings (like RMagick to ImageMagick or Nokogiri to libxml2/libxslt) will have version dependencies on their underlying libraries. RVM does not solve this problem, and this will be the number one problem you face on a Linux distro built for long-term support (and providing that stable / supportable environment by holding back potentially disruptive version updates to libraries).

The Ruby community is very fast-moving, between versions of gems you'll often find  changes to their native library requirements.

You will find that Ruby gems will track newer native libraries then any commercially supported Linux OS provides (including Ubuntu LTS). ie. the RMagick gem. If you want the best experience, you want to be using Chef or Puppet to automate build-up of your hosting systems from faster-moving baselines like Ubuntu or Gentoo, or go to a commercial platform service such as Heroku or EngineYard.

If you simply try to apply traditional systems administration practices to your hosting environment, you will be frustrated by rebuilds and issues moving between base OS versions (ie. if you track Ubuntu server, going from 10.04 to 10.10 to 11.04 etc). Gentoo can be easier, but tends to be less well understood by the available talent pool of system administrators.

A nicely crafted Chef recipe will automate building a server from scratch with consistent base requirements and keep you from having a \vested interest\" in managing a single server instance in the wild. In today's climate
column4: changing servers should be a trivial exercise."
